passage_text: Z line. A cross-striation bisecting the I band of striated muscle myofibrils and serving as the anchoring point of actin filaments at either end of the sarcomere. Z line, a narrow, darkly staining cross-striation that bisects the I band of skeletal muscles. The distance between Z lines is the length of the sarcomere. Also called intermediate disk, Z band, Z disk.

Z line. noun. : any of the dark bands across a striated muscle fiber that mark the junction of actin filaments in adjacent sarcomeres. Britannica.com: Encyclopedia article about Z line. Z-line can refer to: 1  the borders that separate and link sarcomeres within a skeletal muscle. 2  a ban on a user's IP address for the purposes of blocking their access to Internet Relay Chat. 3  the gastroesophageal junction that joins the esophagus to the stomach. 4  Z, a New York City Subway service.

Z line. n. A dark thin protein band to which actin filaments are attached in a striated muscle fiber, marking the boundaries between adjacent sarcomeres. Also called Z band. Z line, a narrow, darkly staining cross-striation that bisects the I band of skeletal muscles. The distance between Z lines is the length of the sarcomere. Also called intermediate disk, Z band, Z disk.

Z line. Definitions: 1. a cross-striation bisecting the I band of striated muscle myofibrils and serving as the anchoring point of actin filaments at either end of the sarcomere. Synonyms: intermediate disc, Z band, Z disc. The definition information for Z line is provided by Stedman's. You can search our medical dictionary here.
